--- Derek James <djames@...> wrote:

> On 6/30/06, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> >
> >   The attached text file describes the problem. As you might guess, I've
> > been working on
> > it. I have had moderate success. My best ANNs can produce 90% of the
> > correct bits for
> > a short path of only 5 steps. For a seven step path the best have been a
> > little over
> > 80%.
> >
> 
> 
> This sounds like an interesting task and a useful area to explore.  It makes
> sense that as the "path" gets longer the ANN performs less and less well.
> I'm not sure that the % of correct bits is the fitness function you want to
> use, though.  If the virtual organism here takes a wrong turn very early on,
> they could end up very, very far from the orginal starting point.
> 
> You may want to simply use distance from the orginal starting point as a
> fitness function.  Or, you might want to use the number of correct responses
> in inverse order, so that if the path was:
> 
> 0 0 1 0 1 0 1 1 0
> 
> and the correct output was:
> 
> 1 0 0 1 0 1 0 1 1
> 
> If the ANN output a 0 for it's first output, it would immediately get a
> fitness of 0.  Or you could have an "undo" feature, so the individual could
> back up.  I don't know which of these options you'd want to play with, but
> if what you really want to be modelling is the navigational task you
> describe, and not merely pattern output, then fitness as a percentage of
> correct bits doesn't seem intuitive to me.
> 
> Nice domain, though, and I'm interested to hear more results and progress.

You are cetainly correct that in the biological case, a one-bit error ruins the return
path, since it no longer takes the animal home.  And also, as you point out, an error
near the start of the return trip has a worse result than one near the end. 

If I was mainly interested in modeling the animal behaviour I would use a different
fitness function.  But my main interest here is in studying a binary ANN used as a state
machine.  In principle a state machine should be able to memorize a sequence of bits,
and then emit a corresponding series of bits.  So I think my ANN is capable of 100%
accuracy for this task, if I can evolve the right set of weights.  Since my goal is 100%
accuracy given any bit sequence as input, I think I'm using the appropriate fitness
function.

I'm not using NEAT, but rather the fully connected binary ANN that I used in the 4Play
project.  I would like to see someone apply NEAT to this problem.

m

Mitchell Timin

I'm proud of http://ANNEvolve.sourceforge.net.  If you want to write software, or articles, or do testing, or research for ANNEvolve, let me know.
